Our Team

Principal Investigator

Joanna (Jo) Culligan

 Blacksburg, VA | Instructor, Human Development and Family Science
Drexel University | MA, Music Therapy
Virginia Tech | BA, Music Technology
Virginia Tech | BS, Marketing Management
joculligan@vt.edu


Jo Culligan is a parent, partner, music therapist, instructor and researcher at Virginia Tech. As a collaborative and creative creature, she strives to make opportunities for and encourage connection between people. She specializes in working with persons who are experiencing dementia and their care-partners using evidence-based musical approaches through neurologic research discovery to improve their communication and engagement. She is passionate about breaking down stigmas associated with aging and dementia. As an instructor, she emphasizes being present as a cornerstone of guidance with the hopes of creating the next generation of gerontology enthusiasts.

Graduate Students

Sara Johnson

 St. Louis, MO
Missouri State University | MS, Clinical Psychology
Missouri University of Science and Technology | BS, Psychology
sarajohnson@vt.edu
LinkedIn


Sara Johnson is an EEG Technician with the IMAGINE Lab at Virginia Tech and a Behavioral Health Coach at Youper AI, a digital mental health care company. As an aspiring psychologist with previous experience providing mental health care services to individuals across the lifespan, she is passionate about increasing access to evidence-based treatments for an array of conditions and promoting equity in healthcare. Outside of work, Sara enjoys reading memoirs, dancing, hanging out with her partner, baking, and exploring new trails in Blacksburg.

Doug Harrison

 NC | Graduate Student, Ph.D. Psychology
George Washington University | B.A. Sociology
Role: EEG Technician
Email: dougjh@vt.edu



Doug Harrison is a graduate student in the department of psychology pursuing a doctorate of psychology focused in developmental science. His research interests include the development of executive functions and cognitive control, their interaction with learning, and neurophysiological correlates of this relationship. His research goals are to translate laboratory findings to individualized and adaptive education.
Doug joined the IMAGINE lab to gain more experience with clinical populations, explore interests in lifespan development, and hyperscanning methods. He hopes to leverage knowledge gained from this experience to future translational work for skill learning and retention, and social learning.
